speaker: POLIXENES
text_entry: SCENE III. A road near the Shepherd's cottage.

speaker: POLIXENES
text_entry: Enter AUTOLYCUS, singing

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: When daffodils begin to peer,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: With heigh! the doxy over the dale,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Why, then comes in the sweet o' the year;

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: The white sheet bleaching on the hedge,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: With heigh! the sweet birds, O, how they sing!

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Doth set my pugging tooth on edge;

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: The lark, that tirra-lyra chants,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: With heigh! with heigh! the thrush and the jay,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Are summer songs for me and my aunts,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: While we lie tumbling in the hay.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: I have served Prince Florizel and in my time

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: wore three-pile; but now I am out of service:

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: But shall I go mourn for that, my dear?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: The pale moon shines by night:

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: And when I wander here and there,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: I then do most go right.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: If tinkers may have leave to live,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: And bear the sow-skin budget,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Then my account I well may, give,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: And in the stocks avouch it.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: lesser linen. My father named me Autolycus; who

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: being, as I am, littered under Mercury, was likewise

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles. With die and

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: drab I purchased this caparison, and my revenue is

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: the silly cheat. Gallows and knock are too powerful

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: on the highway: beating and hanging are terrors to

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: me: for the life to come, I sleep out the thought

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: of it. A prize! a prize!

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Enter Clown

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Let me see: every 'leven wether tods; every tod

speaker: Clown
text_entry: yields pound and odd shilling; fifteen hundred

speaker: Clown
text_entry: shorn. what comes the wool to?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: [Aside]

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: If the springe hold, the cock's mine.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I cannot do't without counters. Let me see; what am

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I to buy for our sheep-shearing feast? Three pound

speaker: Clown
text_entry: of sugar, five pound of currants, rice,--what will

speaker: Clown
text_entry: this sister of mine do with rice? But my father

speaker: Clown
text_entry: hath made her mistress of the feast, and she lays it

speaker: Clown
text_entry: on. She hath made me four and twenty nose-gays for

speaker: Clown
text_entry: the shearers, three-man-song-men all, and very good

speaker: Clown
text_entry: ones; but they are most of them means and bases; but

speaker: Clown
text_entry: one puritan amongst them, and he sings psalms to

speaker: Clown
text_entry: horn-pipes. I must have saffron to colour the warden

speaker: Clown
text_entry: pies; mace; dates?--none, that's out of my note;

speaker: Clown
text_entry: nutmegs, seven; a race or two of ginger, but that I

speaker: Clown
text_entry: may beg; four pound of prunes, and as many of

speaker: Clown
text_entry: raisins o' the sun.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: O that ever I was born!

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Grovelling on the ground

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I' the name of me--

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: O, help me, help me! pluck but off these rags; and

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: then, death, death!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Alack, poor soul! thou hast need of more rags to lay

speaker: Clown
text_entry: on thee, rather than have these off.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: O sir, the loathsomeness of them offends me more

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: than the stripes I have received, which are mighty

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: ones and millions.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Alas, poor man! a million of beating may come to a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: great matter.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: I am robbed, sir, and beaten; my money and apparel

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: ta'en from me, and these detestable things put upon

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: me.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: What, by a horseman, or a footman?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: A footman, sweet sir, a footman.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Indeed, he should be a footman by the garments he

speaker: Clown
text_entry: has left with thee: if this be a horseman's coat,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: it hath seen very hot service. Lend me thy hand,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I'll help thee: come, lend me thy hand.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: O, good sir, tenderly, O!

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Alas, poor soul!

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: O, good sir, softly, good sir! I fear, sir, my

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: shoulder-blade is out.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: How now! canst stand?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: [Picking his pocket]

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Softly, dear sir; good sir, softly. You ha' done me

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: a charitable office.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Dost lack any money? I have a little money for thee.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: No, good sweet sir; no, I beseech you, sir: I have

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: a kinsman not past three quarters of a mile hence,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: unto whom I was going; I shall there have money, or

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: any thing I want: offer me no money, I pray you;

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: that kills my heart.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: What manner of fellow was he that robbed you?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: A fellow, sir, that I have known to go about with

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: troll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of the

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: prince: I cannot tell, good sir, for which of his

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: virtues it was, but he was certainly whipped out of the court.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: His vices, you would say; there's no virtue whipped

speaker: Clown
text_entry: out of the court: they cherish it to make it stay

speaker: Clown
text_entry: there; and yet it will no more but abide.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Vices, I would say, sir. I know this man well: he

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: hath been since an ape-bearer; then a

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: process-server, a bailiff; then he compassed a

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: motion of the Prodigal Son, and married a tinker's

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: wife within a mile where my land and living lies;

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: and, having flown over many knavish professions, he

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: settled only in rogue: some call him Autolycus.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Out upon him! prig, for my life, prig: he haunts

speaker: Clown
text_entry: wakes, fairs and bear-baitings.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Very true, sir; he, sir, he; that's the rogue that

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: put me into this apparel.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Not a more cowardly rogue in all Bohemia: if you had

speaker: Clown
text_entry: but looked big and spit at him, he'ld have run.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: I must confess to you, sir, I am no fighter: I am

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: false of heart that way; and that he knew, I warrant

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: him.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: How do you now?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Sweet sir, much better than I was; I can stand and

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: walk: I will even take my leave of you, and pace

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: softly towards my kinsman's.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Shall I bring thee on the way?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: No, good-faced sir; no, sweet sir.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Then fare thee well: I must go buy spices for our

speaker: Clown
text_entry: sheep-shearing.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Prosper you, sweet sir!

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Exit Clown

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Your purse is not hot enough to purchase your spice.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: I'll be with you at your sheep-shearing too: if I

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: make not this cheat bring out another and the

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: shearers prove sheep, let me be unrolled and my name

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: put in the book of virtue!

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Sings

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Jog on, jog on, the foot-path way,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: And merrily hent the stile-a:

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: A merry heart goes all the day,

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Your sad tires in a mile-a.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
text_entry: Exit
